docs.lead_paragraph: Suffocating debate and resisting modernity, the Catholic Church shrinks its appeal.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column laments the fact that the Catholic Church continues to suffocate debate and resist modernity; cites the uproar caused by Georgetown University's invitation to Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, to speak at a graduation ceremony as the latest example of the church's intolerance.
docs.snippet: Suffocating debate and resisting modernity, the Catholic Church shrinks its appeal.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican assault on women’s rights and health is undeniable, severe and continuing.
docs.abstract: Editorial asserts that the Republican assault on women's rights and health is undeniable, severe and continuing; describes how Republicans in state legislatures across the country and in Washington, DC, are attacking women's rights in the areas of abortion, access to health care, equal pay and domestic violence.
docs.snippet: The Republican assault on women’s rights and health is undeniable, severe and continuing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to “Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care” (Economic View, May 13).
docs.snippet: Readers respond to “Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care” (Economic View, May 13).

docs.lead_paragraph: President Robert G. Mugabe has begun pressuring companies operating in the country to comply with a law requiring that black Zimbabweans own more than half their shares.

headline.seo: Mugabe Seeks Zimbabwe Edge by Pressing for Black Ownership
headline.main: In Land’s Bounty, a Political Chip
headline.print_headline: In Land’s Bounty, A Political Chip

docs.abstract: Fight is brewing in Zimbabwe over who will profit from the nation’s vast bounty of platinum, chromium, nickel and diamonds; Pres Robert G Mugabe has begun pressuring companies operating in the country to comply with a law requiring that black Zimbabweans own more than half their shares.
docs.snippet: President Robert G. Mugabe has begun pressuring companies operating in the country to comply with a law requiring that black Zimbabweans own more than half their shares.

docs.lead_paragraph: Treece, Kan., has been torn down and may soon be erased from maps. But don’t tell that to the Busbys, who live there.

headline.seo: Last Ones Left in Treece, Kan., a Toxic Town
headline.main: Last Ones Left in a Toxic Kansas Town
headline.print_headline: Little House on the Catastrophically Damaged Prairie

docs.abstract: Wes Enzinna article explores the reasons that Della and Tim Busby, last residents of Treece, Kan, have decided to stay despite the environmental contamination, caused by mining operations in the area, that has caused all the other residents to leave.
docs.snippet: Treece, Kan., has been torn down and may soon be erased from maps. But don’t tell that to the Busbys, who live there.

docs.lead_paragraph: To watch the video, press the play button in the bottom-left corner of the image. This Op-Doc video, adapted from my feature-length documentary ''The Waiting Room,'' presents a composite day in the life of patients at Highland Hospital in Oakland, Calif. -- edited from five months of filming in 2010.
docs.snippet: A composite day in the life of patients at Highland Hospital in Oakland, Calif.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''New Guidelines May Sharply Increase Addiction Diagnoses'' (news article, May 12):

headline.main: As the Guide to Mental Ills Is Revised

docs.snippet: Mental health professionals discuss the proposed changes to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.

docs.lead_paragraph: In light of JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar loss, a look at how individuals can manage risk in their own investments with trade-offs and moderation.

headline.seo: Managing Risk in Your Nest Egg - Your Money
headline.main: Getting to Retirement With Minimal Financial Risk
headline.print_headline: Getting to Retirement With Minimal Financial Risk

docs.abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard Your Money column offers advice on how best to discern between hedging and risk taking as a personal investor; notes that the most basic and important form of risk management is investment diversification.
docs.snippet: In light of JPMorgan Chase’s multibillion-dollar loss, a look at how individuals can manage risk in their own investments with trade-offs and moderation.

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal government paid New York State $700 million more in 2009 than the state needed to care for residents with developmental disabilities who lived in its institutions, according to the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline.seo: U.S. Cites Medicaid Overpayments to New York State
headline.main: Medicaid Overpaid New York on Disabled Care, U.S. Says
headline.print_headline: Medicaid Overpaid New York On Disabled Care, U.S. Says

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Dept finds that federal government paid New York State $700 million more in 2009 than state needed to care for institutionalized residents with developmental disabilities; finding suggests that billions of Medicaid dollars earmarked for institutional care in New York were used for other purposes over the last several years; no penalty is recommended, however, because the payments were approved by federal regulators.
docs.snippet: The federal government paid New York State $700 million more in 2009 than the state needed to care for residents with developmental disabilities who lived in its institutions, according to the Department of Health and Human Services.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care'' (Economic View, May 13), Richard H. Thaler criticizes the slippery-slope arguments of those who question the health care law's mandate to buy insurance. But the column overlooks that such arguments are often invoked with good cause. After all, sometimes slopes really are slippery.
docs.snippet: Readers respond to “Slippery-Slope Logic, Applied to Health Care” (Economic View, May 13).
